title: 109_s3717
content: The "Promoting Wellness for Individuals with Disabilities Act of 2006" establishes standards for accessible medical diagnostic equipment under Title V of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973. The Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board will issue standards for accessible medical diagnostic equipment within 9 months of the Promoting Wellness for Individuals with Disabilities Act of 2006. The standards will ensure equipment in medical settings is usable by individuals with disabilities, allowing independent entry, use, and exit. The Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board will issue standards for accessible medical diagnostic equipment, including chairs, weight scales, mammography equipment, x-ray machines, and other radiological equipment commonly used for diagnostic purposes by health professionals. The Board will periodically review and amend the standards. SEC. 399P establishes a Wellness Grant Program for individuals with disabilities under Part P of title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Wellness Grant Program for individuals with disabilities, defined under the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, allows the Secretary to provide grants for promoting good health and wellness, disease prevention, and preventing secondary conditions in individuals with disabilities. Eligibility requires an application. To be eligible for a grant under the Wellness Grant Program, a public or nonprofit entity must submit an application to the Secretary with necessary agreements and information. Authorized activities include programs for smoking cessation, weight control, nutrition, fitness tailored to individuals with disabilities, and preventive health screenings to reduce secondary conditions. The Wellness Grant Program aims to support activities for individuals with disabilities, such as smoking cessation, weight control, nutrition, fitness, and preventive health screenings. The program also includes athletic, exercise, or sports programs in adaptive recreational environments. The Secretary will establish a National Advisory Committee on Wellness for Individuals With Disabilities to set priorities, review grant proposals, and evaluate program progress annually. The Department of Health and Human Services Office on Disability, the Surgeon General or his designee, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, nonprofit organizations representing individuals with disabilities, and individuals with disabilities or their family members are involved in disseminating information about grants under the Wellness Grant Program for Individuals with Disabilities. The Secretary is required to report to Congress within 180 days of the program's enactment. The Wellness Grant Program for Individuals with Disabilities requires the Secretary to report to Congress annually on activities, findings, outcomes, and recommendations from grant projects funded under the program. Authorization of appropriations is provided for making grants under this program. Improving education and training for providing medical services to individuals with disabilities. The text chunk discusses amendments to improve pediatric oral health and training requirements for children's hospitals operating graduate medical education programs. The changes aim to enhance competency and clinical skills in providing oral health services to patients with disabilities, including those with intellectual disabilities. The text chunk discusses amendments to improve competency and clinical skills in providing health care to patients with disabilities, including those with intellectual disabilities, as part of approved graduate medical residency training programs. Amendments are made to training programs for physicians and dentists to enhance their competency in providing healthcare to patients with disabilities, including those with intellectual disabilities. Amendments are made to training programs for physicians and dentists to improve competency and clinical skills in providing healthcare to patients with disabilities, including those with intellectual disabilities. This includes efforts by hospitals, schools of medicine, schools of osteopathic medicine, schools of dentistry, and accrediting bodies to enhance training in undergraduate and graduate medical education. Effective Date: The amendments made to training programs for physicians and dentists to improve competency in providing healthcare to patients with disabilities, including those with intellectual disabilities, shall take effect 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act.
